from M Clay's friends to Gen. Jackson. As to
the charge made by Major Eaton that Mr. .'arkley
was the nagollalor" OF .hr Clay, : authorised to
make propositions or ask a pledge of conditional
character for the vote Of Mr.. Clay and his friends
Mr.. .Markley says : do now solemnly and posi-
lively declare that the charge and inslnuaton are
void of truth | never did, either directly or in
directly, receive from Mr.. Clay or his friends, any
intimation which could be construed even by poit.
cal rancor into such commissioner any thing even
remotely approaching to it, and further, never
have to any one, at any time any OCCASION re-
presented myself, or wished il to be understood,


that twas authorised to receive or to make overtur-
es on the part of Mr. Clay, or his friends" No


language can be more explicit-so no shame is too
deep for the propagators Of The infamous caumnies
which have been built upon this imputed agency OF
Mr. .Narkley, in bargain that never had any e1s-
! tence.

The Letter Of Mr. MARLEY, which we copy to-
day, will be read with great interest by all who yet
entertain doubt the score OF the pretended nego-
tations between the friends of Mr.. ADAMS and Mr.
CLAY preceding the Presidential Election. For
ourselves, WE have wanted nothing of the sort to
convince US of the purity Of that election which
we have always affirmed, and have always believed,
to have been without taint or flaw. We, there
fore, did not, after Gen. JACKSON Letter to
Mr.. BEVERLY, want either Mr.. BucnANAw's or Mr..
MARKLEY's Letter to satisfy us that Gen. JACKSON
had totally misunderstood the source and object OF
Mr., BucHANAN's oyertures to him. Upon others,
however, who did not, like us, witness the whole
scene, from its beginning, the mysterious ousivings
followed by the formal disclosure of Gen. jackson.
may have created some uneasy di5trustul feeling
in regard to the circumstances of that election. To
all such, we say, read MIR. Markley's plain, unvar-
nlshed story, and then answer, there was any ne
gotlaon, or attempt at negotiation, amongst parties
10 the house OF representatives on the eve of the
Presidential Election, Ufo were the parties to il
We believe there was nothing censurabe on either
side; but If there was, it appears thatit assuredy
was not on the part Of those who subsequently voted
for Mr.. Adams.
Philadelphia, Oct. 80, 1927.
From the National MteMgenceY.

Mr. Markley represents himself as having been
Z" originally friendly to the election of General
jackson TO the Presidency"-and having g voted
for him in the Democratic Caucus of 1924" and
subsequently as having, in the capacity of a rep
resentative from Pennsylvania used his best eyer
tons, by every fair and honorable means to promote
his election to the Presidential Chair" Thus then
is proved, as we have always maintained that the
conversation between Mr.. Buchanan and Mr.. Mark.


ley was one between two partizans associated in the
same cause--both being for Jackson. Then. as 70
the conversation it one of Mr.. Buchanan's seeL.
ing; that Mr.. Markiey was urged by Mr.. Buchanan
to see Mr.. Clay to ascertain whether he would not
vote with Pennsylvania for jackson that MIR. M.
has no recollection of having urged Mr. B. to call


on General Jackson {" to the Office of Secretary
Of Staei' that he never used any express;o1


9 about fighting Mr. Adamss friends with their owr
weapons > and, finally, Mr.. Markley says, " M,
Impressions are, that the object of .Mr. Buchanan;
visit was to urge the proprety of my seeing Mr.
Clay, andto give my views as to the Importance If hi
identifying himself with pennsylvania in support .


Gen. Jackson" thus establishing the fact that n


overtures (if overtures they werc\ proceeded fror
the friends of Gen. jackson to Mr.. Clay, and NJ

FROM ot Louis, we learD that the result of the
late expedition, to que the rising Indian hostilities
has been exceedingly fortunate and satisfactory
affording prootof great promptitude on the part of
Gen. Atkinson, and of efficiency on the part Of the
troops, whose station at Jefferson Barracks seems
to be admirably adapted for enabling detachments
to be rapidly moved to any point of disturbance on
the frontier. The General succeeded in obtaining
surrender OF the principal offenders of the Wine-
bagoes engaged in the recent transactions, both at
Prairie du Chem, and in the attack on the keel-boats
returning from Fort Smelling, as we'll as security


to the persons and operations of the people of the
Mining District, on Fever river, and peace and
tranquility to our frontier inhabitants. 1t is SUBJ
ject of much qualification that the difficulties have
been settled without bloodshed.


Nothing but prompt and timely movement of
the troops from Jefferson Barracks, it is said. pre-
vented the Winnebagoes from attacking the mining
people, destroying Prairie du Chem, and making
war upon our frontier settlers These ATTEMPTS. Il


attended with partial success, would have drawn to


their aid all the dsaected of the neighboring tribes


which 1t is believed would not have been very lin
tied. Towards the end Of July there was assem-
bled on the head of Rock river some six hundred
Winnebago warriors and all the bands had secret
ed their women and children. Hostilities would


have followed Immediately had not the causes above
) mentioned prevented it.


AZ to the report published in some of the prints
that the whites we're the aggressors it is utterly
. destitute Of truth. The Indians were the aperes
= sors In Council they offered no excuse for th,
From the National Efel;gencer.

WpHfh
remained on the spot where my services might have
been useful. Frequent intercourse would have
been absolutely necessarily to communicate what was
said and done, and contemplated to be done.


If Major Eaton be credited, he would wholly DIS
prove the statement OF Mr.. Buchanan who AYERS
that he acted solely on his own authority in the con-
yersation held between him aud General Jackson,
and that it was not me but his friend III Pennsyiya-
MIA whose letter determined him to hold such con-
versatieu Mr.. Buchanan's dates do not not agree
with those of Major Eaton who abors in most things
to agree with Mr.. Buchanan. The only converse.
ton he ever had with General Jackson on the Pre-
sdential Election was on the I'd Of January, ac.
cordng to Major Eaton's shelving Mr.. Buchanan
however says he did not call on him. betore his
conversation with the General at a certain day
about the 18th or 10Th of January.


There appears some strange discrepancy in parts
Of the statements of Mr. Buchanan, MIR. lsaacks aud
Major Eaton, which are perfectly rreconcilabe with
the letter of General Jackson. Mr. lsaacks thinks
that his conversation with Mr.. Buchanan may have
been one or two weeks later than Mr.. Buchanan
states it tn have been; but he quite willing to
give up his own recollection for accommodation
sake, and to take the time stated by Mr.. Buchanan,
and agrees that it shall be fixed the 50th OF De-
cember.


| cannot pretend to say when Mr.. Buchanan cal
led Oh General Jackson, as he never communicated
to me-whom major Elton represents as $ the me-
gociator," any conversation between him and Ge-
neral jackson. | do not recollect that Mr. Bucha-
nan aud myself had any conversation from the 3Oth
of December, until after my return to Washington,
on the 5Oth Of January, from Norristown, that is
for the whole month almost Immediately preceding
the election. during the greater part of which time,
was more than hundred miles from the scene 0i
action, the seat Of government.


To undertake to detail the numerous cOnversa-
tions held, pending the presidential election, by the
friends of all the candidates, in which was par
ty or which heard is not my purpose. Indeed nc
consideration would tempt me to divuge private
conversation, especially if the object was to inure
friend, or even political enemy. 1t may, how
ever be proper to state, that in none of the
sations, Of which have any knowledge, was there
any thing said which had the slightest tendency tt


fx or trace either corruption bargain to Mr.
Adams, to General Jackson, to Mr.. Crawford or tt


Mr.. Clay. All that was able to discover among
the friends of the respective candidates, fa


and honorable anxiety and zeal to promote the elec
ton of their favorite candidate


! | close this communication which has been ex
torted from me, in yindicaton of myself and in JUS
tce to those who, through me, have been assailed
and charged with having participated in corrup
transaction. 1t has been to me most unpleasant
duty, one which sincerely wish ! could have beel
spared but thought | owed it to myself, my friend
and my country. l have endeavorcd to avoid often
sive expressions, and personal remarks, save onl


those which have thsught indispensable to my ow
justification, and as bearing directly on the state


ment Of the gentlemen, whose over zeal have Undue


ed them to break into the sanctuary Of privat
friendship, for political purposes,


pbitalplnh;a 0ct an 1907

offence, except that it was done by unsoy.,n,n,
bad men, and not sanctioned by the Chiefs.


Four companies were drawn from Fort snclGr,
to garrison Fort Crawford, and the post was ~
under the command of Major Fowle, pro.ison,%
for twelve months, and supplied with ordinance, os
dnance stores, and ammunition, amply.

to he uuuerstood that was aulhOriSeu 70 receive,
or TO make overtures on the part OF Mr. Clay, his
friends think proper 10 make this general and
unqualified declaration that there may not be left
loop on which to hang doubt on this subject. did
got know until ten days after the election Of Mr.
Adams, that Mr.. Clay had been offered the appoint
ment Of Secretary OF State and il is a well known
fact, that after he had the offer he consulted many
of his friends whether he should, should not,
cept it. He told tie in conversation he did me the
honour to hold with me on the subject, that the
ceptance of II would be to him not only sacrifice
Of domestic happiness, but serious pecunary loss.
l know also, that not only his immediate personal
and political friends, but many OF those who voted
for other candidates, desirous that he should
accept the station, and urged that his country had
claims upon hun paramount to all other considera-
tons, and would never see him suffer from devotion
to her best interests.


ain free to acknowledge that at the time of the
conversation between Mr.. Buchanan and mysef,
my impression was that Gen. Jackson would be
elected, and it was pretty generally talked of, as
well as understood among many Of his friends, that
in the event of his election, Mr. Clay would have
the office of Secretary OF State and doubt not
but | may, in common with others, have mentioned
my opinion to my political friends. These impress
sions were founded on the belief that the western
interest wouh unite in Gen. Jackson's election, and
that with the aid of one or two of the states in favor
Of Mr. Crawford, he would be elected mention
those floating opinions of the day, to show that
have no reserves, and that all said, or did, am
quite willing should be known.


left Washington for Pennsylvania on the morn
ing Of the nth or 18th Of January, 1925, and did
NOT return until Tuesday the S0th of the same
month, the day after Mr. Clay's card had appear
ed in the National Inteligencer. This absence at
this critical uncture, is Of itself sufficient to repel
the idea that took any peculiar interest as to the
arrangements dependant ON who might, or might
not be elected President. recullect a CONVEX sa-
tion with particular friend who travelled with me
in the stage, on my return to Pennsyyania. Tr
him, in the of that conversation, expressed
my regret at not having had an opportunity of free
and general conversation with Mr. Clay on the sub
ject of the Presidential election, aud said that had
some idea OF writing to him soon as l arrived al
Norrstown. We both expressed an anxiety tina,
Mr. Clay should vote with Pennsylvania.


Exception has been taken to my offering the reso
luton of thanks when Mr.. Clay was about retiring
from the speakers chair in 1925. Such resolu
ton it had been customary at the end of congress
to offer, and the house to adopt, as it aid on this
occasion. almost with perfect unanmity. 1t was
my own voluntary act. had no consultation with
any one nor the slightest reference to his course on
the presidential election | offered the resolution
because thought he eminently deserved it. Ii he
as speaker, did not richly earn vote of thanks who
shall presume to think he has pretensons to such ar
honor? The thanks of the house over which he
presided, for a faithful, firm and impartial discharg,
of the duties of the station was hardly earned ane
Willingly awarded thought it his due even thougl
he had differed from Pennsylvania in the choice o
President, she ewed him much for his indefatigabl
exertons in favor Of her policy and best interests
Not only did these considerations but others pronp
me to offer the resolution Of thanks. Mr.. Clay


thought had been uniastly and undeservedly assail
ed for an honest difference of opinion and it wa
painful to see a man who had raised himself by hi
avn talents and exertions to be one of the most di,
tnguished statesmen and orators of the age on
wiio In war and IN peace had never abandoned hi
country, but always stood firmly by her. defendin
bY the lpowers OF his gigantic mind and powerll
eioquence her rights, and boldly procaining he
true pohcy that such should be unthanke
when about TO retire from the speakers chair Of


body of which | had the honor to be member. di
not comport with my feelings or sense of rirht an
wrong; should indeed have considered such a NJ
glect gross drection OF duty.


feel somewhat at loss for terms, sufficient
measured. IN which to speak of the presumptuo,
and unwarranted conclusion at which Major Eatt
has arrived, and the bnld and unceremonious er
thet which 1t has been his pleasure to apply to m


The conversations, reported as they are, by NJ
Buchanan and Mr. Isacks, and laboriously and car
fully directed against me, furnish no evidence. ey,
OF a remote or circumstantal character. to warra
the declaration that was negociator; and fe
assured that nothing but the devoted zeal Of Mai


Eaton, to the cause of General Jackson, could ba


tempted him, in the face Of an intelligent people
use the language he has used. MIR. Buchanan indi
nantly set aside, the imputation. attempted to


cast upon him by General Jackson, of having mad,
proposition or propositions, to him. in the name


Mr.. Clay, or Mr.. Clay's freads, and declares.


express terms, that he always acted, and reprcser


ed himself as acting, on his own personal responsi


iity and was solely moved by Jealous and anxio


desire to manifest his friendship for General Jac


SOIL by assisting to elevate him To tha o,Ia..

differ in more respects from one another than. nor.
haps, in any other State. Some are satisfied win
the Administration and its policy generally Some
form just estimate of the men, but do not ancv
all the measures of the National Government am,
some do not profess nor feel any great respect for
either, but prefer them vastly to the election Of
General Jackson. These facts, and others of .
similar nature, are manifested by the proceedings
of their county meetings, and the correspondence
of distinguished individuals, now made public.
Though they differ in sentiment as TO the present
order of things, there is something in their views
approaching very nearly to uniformity, in oppOsj
tion to the promotion of the General to the presi
dency; fact sufficiently explanatory Of the grounds
on which It calculated that all is not fixed sure. and
safe for the "Combinaton'' in the Ancient Do.


minion.


Many of the Virginians utterly unable to dis


cover what the Nation, and the State of Virginia in


PARTICULARS to gain by the proposed change O


men. They cannot comprehend how Andrew


Jackson is qualified for the post to which he aspires


even admitting that he never had been guilty of the


various acts which are recorded against him. They


cannot understand what has transpired to place Mr.
Adams last in their esteem, when he held the next


place after Mr.. Crawford at their last election


But, however they may differ in other respects


they view the elevation Of the General as calam-


ty, in its various bearings, which ought 10 be de


precated, and which they are resolved, as far as


depends upon them, to avert by the use of all hon


durable means. These men are not to be consid


cred, in all respects, Administration men, but Anti


jackson men.


The most distinguished citizens Of that State are


among this number, though they have, as all men


ought to have, due regard for the Generals mill


tary services.


II orH should always be remembered, that tber4
are a fezy very prominent individuals, in diferen
parts Of the country. whose FUTURE PROMOTION de


pends SOLELY ON the ruin of the men now in power
This ruin mast be ac' mpshed, by some mean', Of
a these few distinguished asplrants never exped
f future political advancement.


!, GrThere is another class Of politicians, of low
! er grade, whose promotion is deemed, by them
) J selves, to be much more probable by the advance
ment of these principals than during the continuan
Of the present order Of things. Hence her labour
g GrCertain Editors Of Newspapers-ior instance
= = lin Virginia, Delaware, and New York. who have
i written and published the severest denuncla'on
against General Jackson, such totally disqualified
/ him for the Presidency and referred to the page
and book for the grounds Of these denuncialions


are mou for cause them thereunto moyIDg'
his most jealous advocates


d He who wishes to form any thing like just esA' .
IS mate Of the Opposition, must remember, among
:, other things, these three classes; they form the


macs Of the most eminently bad portion Of IT. lhes


have been chiefly instrumental in creating the sae


of things which now exists and though many
9 their brethren are censurable for suffering them
> selves to be Influenced by passion prejudice ana
e statements not founded truth argument or eVeu
probability, they are still entitled to all the respec
IS due from one opponent to another in such circun
= stances.
8 Cot MARINus WILLET, the friend and comPan'
ion Of Washington, called to the chair at large
IS and overAowing meeting of the friends OF the Ao'
mins,ration in the city of New ork on "Wednesday
evening last. He is represented as addressing ne
= meeting amidst the most enthusiastic plaudits. he
e spoke of the proclamation Of the memory of Washing


ton by a comparison of him with the Hero Of the
'f Opposition and showed the danger and absurdls
: ofconfding the destinies of the country to mere
soldier, and LETT his impressive warning against suea
Il madness.


es The National Journal has made arrangements 70
report the proceedings in Congress, and to publish
every day, the entire substance of the debates OF M
= " day proceeding. This system originated with TIE
IA Journal though it has had some difficulty to en-
DELAWARE JOURNAL

WILsSG..I.aSq qSssUNS
Tuesday, November 6, AS21.
VIRGINIA..

White Italian or Persian Mulberry.


The citizens of Chester County are respectfully
informed, that by the politeness Of Or. .abraham
Stout, was furnished for planting, with parcel Of
seeds from the Italian Mulberry, introduced by the
late Bishop Etwein, at Bethehem.-They are of the
most approved kind for the food of the Silk-Worm.
have now eight or ten thousand sets, which | wish
togve away, to persons in different parts of the
county, with view to encourage the production Of
silk. Each person applying shall be welcome to an
hundred plants, until Ave thousand are gone then
if the applications are numerous, the number to each
will be fifty. until eight or ten thousand (the half
have) are disposed of-For an hundred, "a bed should
be prepared rendering the ground deeply mellow,
and moderately rich, fifty feet long and three feet
wide so as place the roots in two rows foot apart
The next fall the spring thereafter, they will do ts
set out in orchard fashion, whether there shall be
room for them. Any time in the month Of Novem.
ber they may be removed. The leaves will be vau
able in two years. G. MINER.


Spring Grove, Oct. 27, 1897.


P. s. 1t may be proper to say, that the ensuin.
winter, the Report on raising the mulberry and pro
ducing silk, will be made by the Secretary of th'
Treasury, which will contain and disseminate all tht
information that is valuable upon the subject.

- OtO@ 90 o.
From the Village Record.


SILK.
White Italian or Persian Mulberry.

FATNING SWINE, &c.-We are informed by
Judge Peters Of Pennsylvania, formerly President
of the Philadelphia Agricultural Society, in COM
munlcaton which appeared in the Philadelphia
American Daily Advertiser that sour food is the
most grateful and alimentary to swne." One gal
lon of sour wash goes farther than two of sweet.
mean the wash aciduated to the degree required
for dstillatlon, not acetous.


Dry rotten wood kept constantly in styes for fat
ting hogs, TO eat at pleasure is good thing, but
Will take the liberty to mention whatl think better;
we have three backsmiths in this tow land my hogs
eat up all the ashes and cnaers they make we haul
it into pens by cart loads, and the hogs will de-
YOUR this at times with avdity than their ordi-
nary food


Charcoal, it has been said, will answer a similar
if not more valuable purpose than either cnders
or rotten wood. If swine we're supplied with a
small quantity OF coal (accordng to statement OF
an Ohio farner,) say two pieces day to each,
about the size OF hens egg they will discontinue
roofing, remain quiet, and iatten faster than
they will otherwise. Charcoal will operate on the
human frame cathartic and, probably may
have the effect on the animal we are treating
o 1t so. IT may superseded the necessity of using
brimstone, antimony and other drugs with which
hogs are often dosed. At any rate it will cost but
little to give them constant access to Goals which
may be siited or raked from your Fireplace and they
will be induced by instinct to consume such guam
titles will promote their health and expedite their
fattenng.


| When you first commence fattening your swine,
care should be used not to give them more than they
will eat with an appetite. If they become gorged
OF cloyed, their thriving is retarded, and there is
danger from saggers, and other diseases consequent
upon repetion or the high living to which these ou,
footed epicures addicted.
From the New England Farmer.

We believe there was nothing censurabe on either

was not on the part Of those who subsequently voted
for Mr.. Adams.

bled on the head of Rock river some six hundred

ed their women and children. Hostilities would

that he acted solely on his own authority in the con-
yersation held between him aud General Jackson,
and that it was not me but his friend III Pennsyiya-
MIA whose letter determined him to hold such con-
versatieu Mr.. Buchanan's dates do not not agree
with those of Major Eaton who abors in most things
to agree with Mr.. Buchanan. The only converse.
ton he ever had with General Jackson on the Pre-
sdential Election was on the I'd Of January, ac.
cordng to Major Eaton's shelving Mr.. Buchanan
however says he did not call on him. betore his
conversation with the General at a certain day
about the 18th or 10Th of January.


There appears some strange discrepancy in parts
Of the statements of Mr. Buchanan, MIR. lsaacks aud
Major Eaton, which are perfectly rreconcilabe with
the letter of General Jackson. Mr. lsaacks thinks
that his conversation with Mr.. Buchanan may have
been one or two weeks later than Mr.. Buchanan
states it tn have been; but he quite willing to
give up his own recollection for accommodation
sake, and to take the time stated by Mr.. Buchanan,
and agrees that it shall be fixed the 50th OF De-
cember.


| cannot pretend to say when Mr.. Buchanan cal
led Oh General Jackson, as he never communicated
to me-whom major Elton represents as $ the me-
gociator," any conversation between him and Ge-
neral jackson. | do not recollect that Mr. Bucha-
nan aud myself had any conversation from the 3Oth
of December, until after my return to Washington,
on the 5Oth Of January, from Norristown, that is
for the whole month almost Immediately preceding
the election. during the greater part of which time,
was more than hundred miles from the scene 0i
action, the seat Of government.


To undertake to detail the numerous cOnversa-
tions held, pending the presidential election, by the
friends of all the candidates, in which was par
ty or which heard is not my purpose. Indeed nc
consideration would tempt me to divuge private
conversation, especially if the object was to inure
friend, or even political enemy. 1t may, how
ever be proper to state, that in none of the
sations, Of which have any knowledge, was there
any thing said which had the slightest tendency tt


fx or trace either corruption bargain to Mr.
Adams, to General Jackson, to Mr.. Crawford or tt


Mr.. Clay. All that was able to discover among
the friends of the respective candidates, fa


and honorable anxiety and zeal to promote the elec
ton of their favorite candidate


! | close this communication which has been ex
torted from me, in yindicaton of myself and in JUS
tce to those who, through me, have been assailed
and charged with having participated in corrup
transaction. 1t has been to me most unpleasant
duty, one which sincerely wish ! could have beel
spared but thought | owed it to myself, my friend
and my country. l have endeavorcd to avoid often
sive expressions, and personal remarks, save onl


those which have thsught indispensable to my ow
justification, and as bearing directly on the state


ment Of the gentlemen, whose over zeal have Undue


ed them to break into the sanctuary Of privat
friendship, for political purposes,


pbitalplnh;a 0ct an 1907

offence, except that it was done by unsoy.,n,n,
bad men, and not sanctioned by the Chiefs.


Four companies were drawn from Fort snclGr,
to garrison Fort Crawford, and the post was ~
under the command of Major Fowle, pro.ison,%
for twelve months, and supplied with ordinance, os
dnance stores, and ammunition, amply.

to he uuuerstood that was aulhOriSeu 70 receive,
or TO make overtures on the part OF Mr. Clay, his
friends think proper 10 make this general and
unqualified declaration that there may not be left
loop on which to hang doubt on this subject. did
got know until ten days after the election Of Mr.
Adams, that Mr.. Clay had been offered the appoint
ment Of Secretary OF State and il is a well known
fact, that after he had the offer he consulted many
of his friends whether he should, should not,
cept it. He told tie in conversation he did me the
honour to hold with me on the subject, that the
ceptance of II would be to him not only sacrifice
Of domestic happiness, but serious pecunary loss.
l know also, that not only his immediate personal
and political friends, but many OF those who voted
for other candidates, desirous that he should
accept the station, and urged that his country had
claims upon hun paramount to all other considera-
tons, and would never see him suffer from devotion
to her best interests.


ain free to acknowledge that at the time of the
conversation between Mr.. Buchanan and mysef,
my impression was that Gen. Jackson would be
elected, and it was pretty generally talked of, as
well as understood among many Of his friends, that
in the event of his election, Mr. Clay would have
the office of Secretary OF State and doubt not
but | may, in common with others, have mentioned
my opinion to my political friends. These impress
sions were founded on the belief that the western
interest wouh unite in Gen. Jackson's election, and
that with the aid of one or two of the states in favor
Of Mr. Crawford, he would be elected mention
those floating opinions of the day, to show that
have no reserves, and that all said, or did, am
quite willing should be known.


left Washington for Pennsylvania on the morn
ing Of the nth or 18th Of January, 1925, and did
NOT return until Tuesday the S0th of the same
month, the day after Mr. Clay's card had appear
ed in the National Inteligencer. This absence at
this critical uncture, is Of itself sufficient to repel
the idea that took any peculiar interest as to the
arrangements dependant ON who might, or might
not be elected President. recullect a CONVEX sa-
tion with particular friend who travelled with me
in the stage, on my return to Pennsyyania. Tr
him, in the of that conversation, expressed
my regret at not having had an opportunity of free
and general conversation with Mr. Clay on the sub
ject of the Presidential election, aud said that had
some idea OF writing to him soon as l arrived al
Norrstown. We both expressed an anxiety tina,
Mr. Clay should vote with Pennsylvania.


Exception has been taken to my offering the reso
luton of thanks when Mr.. Clay was about retiring
from the speakers chair in 1925. Such resolu
ton it had been customary at the end of congress
to offer, and the house to adopt, as it aid on this
occasion. almost with perfect unanmity. 1t was
my own voluntary act. had no consultation with
any one nor the slightest reference to his course on
the presidential election | offered the resolution
because thought he eminently deserved it. Ii he
as speaker, did not richly earn vote of thanks who
shall presume to think he has pretensons to such ar
honor? The thanks of the house over which he
presided, for a faithful, firm and impartial discharg,
of the duties of the station was hardly earned ane
Willingly awarded thought it his due even thougl
he had differed from Pennsylvania in the choice o
President, she ewed him much for his indefatigabl
exertons in favor Of her policy and best interests
Not only did these considerations but others pronp
me to offer the resolution Of thanks. Mr.. Clay


thought had been uniastly and undeservedly assail
ed for an honest difference of opinion and it wa
painful to see a man who had raised himself by hi
avn talents and exertions to be one of the most di,
tnguished statesmen and orators of the age on
wiio In war and IN peace had never abandoned hi
country, but always stood firmly by her. defendin
bY the lpowers OF his gigantic mind and powerll
eioquence her rights, and boldly procaining he
true pohcy that such should be unthanke
when about TO retire from the speakers chair Of


body of which | had the honor to be member. di
not comport with my feelings or sense of rirht an
wrong; should indeed have considered such a NJ
glect gross drection OF duty.


feel somewhat at loss for terms, sufficient
measured. IN which to speak of the presumptuo,
and unwarranted conclusion at which Major Eatt
has arrived, and the bnld and unceremonious er
thet which 1t has been his pleasure to apply to m


The conversations, reported as they are, by NJ
Buchanan and Mr. Isacks, and laboriously and car
fully directed against me, furnish no evidence. ey,
OF a remote or circumstantal character. to warra
the declaration that was negociator; and fe
assured that nothing but the devoted zeal Of Mai


Eaton, to the cause of General Jackson, could ba


tempted him, in the face Of an intelligent people
use the language he has used. MIR. Buchanan indi
nantly set aside, the imputation. attempted to


cast upon him by General Jackson, of having mad,
proposition or propositions, to him. in the name


Mr.. Clay, or Mr.. Clay's freads, and declares.


express terms, that he always acted, and reprcser


ed himself as acting, on his own personal responsi


iity and was solely moved by Jealous and anxio


desire to manifest his friendship for General Jac


SOIL by assisting to elevate him To tha o,Ia..

full articles.headline:
DELAWARE JOURNAL

WILsSG..I.aSq qSssUNS
Tuesday, November 6, AS21.

VIRGINIA..
full articles.article:
differ in more respects from one another than. nor.
haps, in any other State. Some are satisfied win
the Administration and its policy generally Some
form just estimate of the men, but do not ancv
all the measures of the National Government am,
some do not profess nor feel any great respect for
either, but prefer them vastly to the election Of
General Jackson. These facts, and others of .
similar nature, are manifested by the proceedings
of their county meetings, and the correspondence
of distinguished individuals, now made public.
Though they differ in sentiment as TO the present
order of things, there is something in their views
approaching very nearly to uniformity, in oppOsj
tion to the promotion of the General to the presi
dency; fact sufficiently explanatory Of the grounds
on which It calculated that all is not fixed sure. and
safe for the "Combinaton'' in the Ancient Do.


minion.


Many of the Virginians utterly unable to dis


cover what the Nation, and the State of Virginia in


PARTICULARS to gain by the proposed change O


men. They cannot comprehend how Andrew


Jackson is qualified for the post to which he aspires


even admitting that he never had been guilty of the


various acts which are recorded against him. They


cannot understand what has transpired to place Mr.
Adams last in their esteem, when he held the next


place after Mr.. Crawford at their last election


But, however they may differ in other respects


they view the elevation Of the General as calam-


ty, in its various bearings, which ought 10 be de


precated, and which they are resolved, as far as


depends upon them, to avert by the use of all hon


durable means. These men are not to be consid


cred, in all respects, Administration men, but Anti


jackson men.


The most distinguished citizens Of that State are


among this number, though they have, as all men


ought to have, due regard for the Generals mill


tary services.


II orH should always be remembered, that tber4
are a fezy very prominent individuals, in diferen
parts Of the country. whose FUTURE PROMOTION de


pends SOLELY ON the ruin of the men now in power
This ruin mast be ac' mpshed, by some mean', Of
a these few distinguished asplrants never exped
f future political advancement.


!, GrThere is another class Of politicians, of low
! er grade, whose promotion is deemed, by them
) J selves, to be much more probable by the advance
ment of these principals than during the continuan
Of the present order Of things. Hence her labour
g GrCertain Editors Of Newspapers-ior instance
= = lin Virginia, Delaware, and New York. who have
i written and published the severest denuncla'on
against General Jackson, such totally disqualified
/ him for the Presidency and referred to the page
and book for the grounds Of these denuncialions


are mou for cause them thereunto moyIDg'
his most jealous advocates


d He who wishes to form any thing like just esA' .
IS mate Of the Opposition, must remember, among
:, other things, these three classes; they form the


macs Of the most eminently bad portion Of IT. lhes


have been chiefly instrumental in creating the sae


of things which now exists and though many
9 their brethren are censurable for suffering them
> selves to be Influenced by passion prejudice ana
e statements not founded truth argument or eVeu
probability, they are still entitled to all the respec
IS due from one opponent to another in such circun
= stances.
8 Cot MARINus WILLET, the friend and comPan'
ion Of Washington, called to the chair at large
IS and overAowing meeting of the friends OF the Ao'
mins,ration in the city of New ork on "Wednesday
evening last. He is represented as addressing ne
= meeting amidst the most enthusiastic plaudits. he
e spoke of the proclamation Of the memory of Washing


ton by a comparison of him with the Hero Of the
'f Opposition and showed the danger and absurdls
: ofconfding the destinies of the country to mere
soldier, and LETT his impressive warning against suea
Il madness.


es The National Journal has made arrangements 70
report the proceedings in Congress, and to publish
every day, the entire substance of the debates OF M
= " day proceeding. This system originated with TIE
IA Journal though it has had some difficulty to en-

full articles.headline:
- OtO@ 90 o.
From the Village Record.


SILK.

White Italian or Persian Mulberry.
full articles.article:
White Italian or Persian Mulberry.


The citizens of Chester County are respectfully
informed, that by the politeness Of Or. .abraham
Stout, was furnished for planting, with parcel Of
seeds from the Italian Mulberry, introduced by the
late Bishop Etwein, at Bethehem.-They are of the
most approved kind for the food of the Silk-Worm.
have now eight or ten thousand sets, which | wish
togve away, to persons in different parts of the
county, with view to encourage the production Of
silk. Each person applying shall be welcome to an
hundred plants, until Ave thousand are gone then
if the applications are numerous, the number to each
will be fifty. until eight or ten thousand (the half
have) are disposed of-For an hundred, "a bed should
be prepared rendering the ground deeply mellow,
and moderately rich, fifty feet long and three feet
wide so as place the roots in two rows foot apart
The next fall the spring thereafter, they will do ts
set out in orchard fashion, whether there shall be
room for them. Any time in the month Of Novem.
ber they may be removed. The leaves will be vau
able in two years. G. MINER.


Spring Grove, Oct. 27, 1897.


P. s. 1t may be proper to say, that the ensuin.
winter, the Report on raising the mulberry and pro
ducing silk, will be made by the Secretary of th'
Treasury, which will contain and disseminate all tht
information that is valuable upon the subject.

full articles.headline: From the New England Farmer.
full articles.article:
FATNING SWINE, &c.-We are informed by
Judge Peters Of Pennsylvania, formerly President
of the Philadelphia Agricultural Society, in COM
munlcaton which appeared in the Philadelphia
American Daily Advertiser that sour food is the
most grateful and alimentary to swne." One gal
lon of sour wash goes farther than two of sweet.
mean the wash aciduated to the degree required
for dstillatlon, not acetous.


Dry rotten wood kept constantly in styes for fat
ting hogs, TO eat at pleasure is good thing, but
Will take the liberty to mention whatl think better;
we have three backsmiths in this tow land my hogs
eat up all the ashes and cnaers they make we haul
it into pens by cart loads, and the hogs will de-
YOUR this at times with avdity than their ordi-
nary food


Charcoal, it has been said, will answer a similar
if not more valuable purpose than either cnders
or rotten wood. If swine we're supplied with a
small quantity OF coal (accordng to statement OF
an Ohio farner,) say two pieces day to each,
about the size OF hens egg they will discontinue
roofing, remain quiet, and iatten faster than
they will otherwise. Charcoal will operate on the
human frame cathartic and, probably may
have the effect on the animal we are treating
o 1t so. IT may superseded the necessity of using
brimstone, antimony and other drugs with which
hogs are often dosed. At any rate it will cost but
little to give them constant access to Goals which
may be siited or raked from your Fireplace and they
will be induced by instinct to consume such guam
titles will promote their health and expedite their
fattenng.


| When you first commence fattening your swine,
care should be used not to give them more than they
will eat with an appetite. If they become gorged
OF cloyed, their thriving is retarded, and there is
danger from saggers, and other diseases consequent
upon repetion or the high living to which these ou,
footed epicures addicted.
